newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Inter-Continental Hotels accelerates China push.
newsitem.headline: Inter-Continental Hotels accelerates China push.

text.p: Inter-Continental Hotels and Resorts, one of the world's biggest privately owned luxury-hotel chains, said on Wednesday it has formed a joint venture with the Hong Kong-based Dynasty Group to accelerate expansion in China.
The joint venture would add hotels in Beijing, Chengdu, Qingdao and Xian to Inter-Continental's network, bringing its portfolio in China to six properties.

"This agreement moves us one step closer to our goal of having 25 hotels in China by the year 2010," Marcello Pigozzo, Inter-Continental's President, Asia Pacific, told a news conference in Hong Kong.
Dynasty is involved in the development, financing and management of hotels in China, where it currently has four.
He refused to disclose the level of investment the company plans in its push into China, saying only that in the past decade it had invested more than US$100 million in the region.
The hotel group began a rapid expansion programme in the Asia-Pacific region last year, with China and India earmarked as key development targets.

Chairman Yuji Tsutsumi said the Asia Pacific region had not only become a rapidly growing focus for international tourism, but that Asians would soon make up the greater proportion of global travellers.
"We estimate that by the year 2005 Asians will comprise more than 50 percent of global travellers on airlines alone," he said.
Inter-Continental had planned a stock market flotation next year, but last month announced it was postponing its listing until early 1998.
Tsutsumi said on Wednesday that the company was still reviewing its stock flotation plans after the death of former chief executive Sueaki Takaoka in March.
"Inter-Continental should not be owned by one company and one nationality," Dynasty Group Chairman Andrew Chan told the news conference. "Going public would be a great advantage."

Inter-Continental, a U.S.-based chain and part of Japan's Saison Corporation, owns more than 100 luxury hotels under its own name and at least 23 through the Forum Hotels chain. It runs a number of other hotels, some under different names, through joint ventures.
The chain hopes to increase the number of hotels it owns or manages by at least 50 from around 180 by the year 2000.
